document.text: your questions 1st. I am in favor of the free and unlimited coinage of both gold and ilver at the ratio of 16 to 1. 2nd. It I am elected Governor aud a vacancy should occur, by res ignation or otherwise, in either of the United States Senators from this State, I should consider it my duty to appoint a Senator thoroughly in accord with the platfbrm to be adopted at the next Democratic State Convention, which platform I am certain will contain a declara tion in favor of the free and unlim ited coinage of silver. Yours very truly, J. T aylor E llyson . Mr. A. H. Clement, Editor A. aud B. T im es  D ear sir  I suppose it is ueed less to comment on the gubernator- iol contest as far as Appomattox is conceined, for the people of Appo mattox are as sure to select Tyler and Mann delegates to Roanoke as the 10th of June rolls around. But is worthy of comment that Mr. Ellyson has in a recent issue of the Dispatch defined his position on the silver question by declaring himself n favor of the tree and unlimited coinage of gold and silver at the atio of 16 to 1, and is flooding the county with marked copies of the ssne. It is well-known that Mr. Ellyson hesitated to accept the chairmanship of the State Committee because he ra op, osed to the silver plank of the Chicago platform and feared his position would do harm us its chair man. The announcement of his changed iews at this late and critical mo ment in his canvass is a matter open to conjecture. Is-it a vote catcher? If it is it is a leaky one. The man that is elastic enough to be pressed out of his natural attitude is elastic enough to reassume it when the pressure is removed. We prefer a man that stands nat urally and easily on the Chicago platform, silver plank and all a man like J. Hoge Tyler. Four year ago Mr. Tyler was honest enough to declare himself for free silver when it was unpopular md was honest enough to stick to it, and went down to defeat clinging to his honest convictions. Now would it not be wiser in Mr. Ellyson to do the same if he would aspire to be Governor in the future. Very truly yours, X.
